content:
Hi all, I've recently posted a question on twitter asking why the definition of an enriched natural transformation is the way it is: https://twitter.com/bgavran3/status/1331229889756848132

Interestingly enough, exactly a year later I ended up thinking about the same question. @PaoloPMath's perspective here https://twitter.com/PaoloPMath/status/1194605406951227393) helped quite a bit, and after some discussions with @mattecapu some more exciting questions came up! 1/n https://twitter.com/bgavran3/status/1193951310283976706

- Bruno Gavranović (@bgavran3)

I'm only now realizing that perhaps I should've been using this chat all along for all my CT queries :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes:
The question is pretty well laid out on the link, but the main idea is: why does an enriched natural transformation use maps from the monoidal unit III, as opposed from some object P:VP : \mathcal{V}P:V?

Using objects that are different from the monoidal unit seems to be in line what enriched CT is all about, and the whole reasoning of using weighted limits. But Kelly's enriched CT book (and all other sources I could find) define it as a map from the monoidal unit.

I want to point out that using III is not necessary to express naturality. Well, it is if you do it the way Kelly does, using the unitors of V\mathcal VV, but it is not if you just write down the equation expressing naturality.
What I mean here is that given two V\mathcal VV-functors F,G:C→DF, G : \mathbf C \to \mathbf DF,G:C→D, one can define a V\mathcal VV-natural transformation α:F→G\alpha:F \to Gα:F→G to be an obCob \mathbf CobC-indexed collection of morphisms αX:P→D(FX,GX)\alpha_X : P \to \mathbf D(FX, GX)αX​:P→D(FX,GX).
Then you ask naturality in this way: given f:Q→C(X,Y)f : Q \to \mathbf C(X,Y)f:Q→C(X,Y), you want

αX⊗(f;GX,Y);∘D=((f;FX,Y⊗αY);∘D\alpha_X \otimes (f;G_{X,Y}) ; \circ_D = ((f;F_{X,Y} \otimes \alpha_Y) ; \circ_DαX​⊗(f;GX,Y​);∘D​=((f;FX,Y​⊗αY​);∘D​

Fixing PPP for all the αX\alpha_XαX​ seems unavoidable, since there would be no way to express naturality then (basically, the left and right hand of the above equation would have a different source!)
To relax this, one could go galaxy brain and use the end definition of natural transformations:
[F,G]=∫X∈CD(FX,GX)[F,G] = \int_{X \in \mathbf C} \mathbf D(FX,GX)[F,G]=∫X∈C​D(FX,GX)
Then one would add a weight W:C→VW : \mathcal C \to \mathcal VW:C→V and define WWW-weighted natural transformations to be
[F,G]W=∫X∈C[WX,D(FX,GX)][F,G]^W = \int_{X \in \mathbf C} [WX, \mathbf D(FX,GX)][F,G]W=∫X∈C​[WX,D(FX,GX)]
Indeed, this is what one does to define co/limits in the enriched settings! So why not here?

Matteo Capucci said:

[D]efine WWW-weighted natural transformations to be
[F,G]W=∫X∈C[WX,D(FX,GX)][F,G]^W = \int_{X \in \mathbf C} [WX, \mathbf D(FX,GX)][F,G]W=∫X∈C​[WX,D(FX,GX)]

Also, let me precise that one would then consider natural transformations F→GF \to GF→G to be natural transformations with any weight, so terms of ∫W[F,G]W\int^W [F,G]^W∫W[F,G]W or simply ∐W[F,G]W\coprod_W [F,G]^W∐W​[F,G]W.
I'm fairly sure putting all of them togheter saves their compositional structure: if you have natural transformations α:[F,G]\alpha : [F,G]α:[F,G] (weighted, say, by WWW) and β:[G,H]\beta : [G,H]β:[G,H] (weighted by TTT), you should be able to compose them by tensoring, obtaining βα:[F,H]\beta\alpha : [F,H]βα:[F,H] weighted by W⊗TW \otimes TW⊗T.
The identity natural transformation is I→1XC(X,X)→FD(FX,FX)I \overset{1_X}\to \mathbf C(X,X) \overset{F}\to \mathbf D(FX,FX)I→1X​C(X,X)→FD(FX,FX), and indeed it is the unit of the composition defined above

I guess a more down-to-earth viewpoint is what's implicitly in the first few messages of the twitter thread: V\mathcal{V}V-functors between two V\mathcal{V}V-categories form a V\mathcal{V}V-category, and the morphisms of the underlying category are the enriched natural transformations.

Whether looking at the underlying category of a V\mathcal{V}V-category is useful or not probably depends quite a lot on V\mathcal{V}V. For example, for V\mathcal{V}V = abelian groups it's quite a sensible thing to do.

Reid Barton said:

Whether looking at the underlying category of a V\mathcal{V}V-category is useful or not probably depends quite a lot on V\mathcal{V}V. For example, for V\mathcal{V}V = abelian groups it's quite a sensible thing to do.

Right, but the idea is to set up the definitions so that they work for all choices of V\mathcal{V}V. It can be argued that for Lawvere metric spaces the definition of an enriched natural transformation doesn't quite work the way it's set up, or at the very least, misses a lot of interesting structure.
Well don't pass to the underlying category if your V\mathcal{V}V is not the right sort to do it
I'm not suggesting to pass to the ordinary category. I want to stay in the enriched setting, but the widely used definition seems to suggest that we have to pass back, if we want to consider 2-cells.
Well that's what a 2-cell is--a morphism of an ordinary category

Perhaps the relevant distinction is that it is only sensible to consider individual enriched natural transformations in certain situations, whereas considering the collection of enriched natural transformations between two enriched functors is always sensible (for exactly the same reason that passing to the underlying category is only sensible in some settings).
And, in your instance, considering individual natural transformations is not something you want to do.

Matteo Capucci said:

αX⊗(f;GX,Y);∘D=((f;FX,Y⊗αY);∘D\alpha_X \otimes (f;G_{X,Y}) ; \circ_D = ((f;F_{X,Y} \otimes \alpha_Y) ; \circ_DαX​⊗(f;GX,Y​);∘D​=((f;FX,Y​⊗αY​);∘D​

The left and right hand sides seem to have different domains! The left hand side has domain P⊗QP\otimes QP⊗Q and the right hand side has domain Q⊗PQ\otimes PQ⊗P. Is there a way to fix this?

Matteo Capucci (he/him) said:

Matteo Capucci (he/him) said:

[D]efine WWW-weighted natural transformations to be
[F,G]W=∫X∈C[WX,D(FX,GX)][F,G]^W = \int_{X \in \mathbf C} [WX, \mathbf D(FX,GX)][F,G]W=∫X∈C​[WX,D(FX,GX)]

Also, let me precise that one would then consider natural transformations F→GF \to GF→G to be natural transformations with any weight, so terms of ∫W[F,G]W\int^W [F,G]^W∫W[F,G]W or simply ∐W[F,G]W\coprod_W [F,G]^W∐W​[F,G]W.
I'm fairly sure putting all of them togheter saves their compositional structure: if you have natural transformations α:[F,G]\alpha : [F,G]α:[F,G] (weighted, say, by WWW) and β:[G,H]\beta : [G,H]β:[G,H] (weighted by TTT), you should be able to compose them by tensoring, obtaining βα:[F,H]\beta\alpha : [F,H]βα:[F,H] weighted by W⊗TW \otimes TW⊗T.
The identity natural transformation is I→1XC(X,X)→FD(FX,FX)I \overset{1_X}\to \mathbf C(X,X) \overset{F}\to \mathbf D(FX,FX)I→1X​C(X,X)→FD(FX,FX), and indeed it is the unit of the composition defined above

Me an Fosco have been working on a project involving precisely this notion! At least for the case V=Sets\mathcal{V}=\mathsf{Sets}V=Sets, this indeed works (where you can more generally take WWW to be of the form W ⁣:Cop×C⟶SetsW\colon\mathcal{C}^\mathsf{op}\times\mathcal{C}\longrightarrow\mathsf{Sets}W:Cop×C⟶Sets), giving a kind of "graded Godement calculus" of natural transformations and weighted natural transformations. The only problem we are having with the general case is that it seems it's quite hard (if possible at all) to define the end

∫X∈C[WXX,HomD(F(X),G(X))]V\int_{X\in\mathcal{C}}[W^{X}_{X},\textbf{Hom}_{\mathcal{D}}(F(X),G(X))]_{\mathcal{V}}∫X∈C​[WXX​,HomD​(F(X),G(X))]V​

without requiring V\mathcal{V}V to have diagonals: how does one define a V\mathcal{V}V-functor (X,Y)↦[WYX,F(X),G(Y)]V(X,Y)\mapsto[W^{X}_{Y},F(X),G(Y)]_{\mathcal{V}}(X,Y)↦[WYX​,F(X),G(Y)]V​ without them?
It's nice to hear this is interesting you as well!

Something like

∫X∈CC(X,Y)⋔V∫Y∈C[WYX,D(FX,GY)]V\int_{X \in \mathcal C} \mathcal C(X, Y) \pitchfork_{\mathcal V} \int_{Y \in \mathcal C} [W^X_Y, \mathcal D(FX, GY)]_{\mathcal V}∫X∈C​C(X,Y)⋔V​∫Y∈C​[WYX​,D(FX,GY)]V​

which I guess can be Fubinized to

∬X,Y∈CC(X,Y)⋔V[WYX,D(FX,GY)]V\iint_{X,Y \in \mathcal C} \mathcal C(X,Y) \pitchfork_{\mathcal V} [W^X_Y, \mathcal D(FX, GY)]_{\mathcal V}∬X,Y∈C​C(X,Y)⋔V​[WYX​,D(FX,GY)]V​
I don't know if I'm fooling myself here though

The idea is to work with (X,Y,X′,Y′)↦[WYX,D(FX′,GY′)]V(X,Y,X',Y') \mapsto [W^X_Y, \mathcal D(FX', GY')]_{\mathcal V}(X,Y,X′,Y′)↦[WYX​,D(FX′,GY′)]V​ so we don't need to duplicate variables. Then we collapse the duplicate variables by imposing equality

Matteo Capucci (he/him) said:

The idea is to work with (X,Y,X′,Y′)↦[WYX,D(FX′,GY′)]V(X,Y,X',Y') \mapsto [W^X_Y, \mathcal D(FX', GY')]_{\mathcal V}(X,Y,X′,Y′)↦[WYX​,D(FX′,GY′)]V​ so we don't need to duplicate variables. Then we collapse the duplicate variables by imposing equality

This is a nice idea! I think we're still trapped though: the assignment

(A,B)↦∫Y[WYB,D(F(A),G(Y))]V(A,B) \mapsto \int_{Y}[W^{B}_{Y},\mathcal{D}(F(A),G(Y))]_{\mathcal{V}}(A,B)↦∫Y​[WYB​,D(F(A),G(Y))]V​

defines a V\mathcal{V}V-bifunctor ∫Y[WY−2,D(F(−1),G(Y))]V ⁣:Cop⊠VC⟶V\int_{Y}[W^{-_{2}}_{Y},\mathcal{D}(F(-_{1}),G(Y))]_{\mathcal{V}}\colon\mathcal{C}^{\mathsf{op}}\boxtimes_{\mathcal{V}}\mathcal{C}\longrightarrow\mathcal{V}∫Y​[WY−2​​,D(F(−1​),G(Y))]V​:Cop⊠V​C⟶V which when combined with¹ C(−,K) ⁣:Cop⟶V\mathcal{C}(-,K)\colon\mathcal{C}^\mathsf{op}\longrightarrow\mathcal{V}C(−,K):Cop⟶V would give a V\mathcal{V}V-functor

C(−3,K)⋔V∫Y[WY−2,D(F(−1),G(Y))]V\mathcal{C}(-_{3},K)\pitchfork_\mathcal{V}\int_{Y}[W^{-_{2}}_{Y},\mathcal{D}(F(-_{1}),G(Y))]_{\mathcal{V}}C(−3​,K)⋔V​∫Y​[WY−2​​,D(F(−1​),G(Y))]V​

from C⊠VCop⊠VC\mathcal{C}\boxtimes_{\mathcal{V}}\mathcal{C}^{\mathsf{op}}\boxtimes_{\mathcal{V}}\mathcal{C}C⊠V​Cop⊠V​C to V\mathcal{V}V. On the other hand, to get a functor Cop⊠VC⟶V\mathcal{C}^{\mathsf{op}}\boxtimes_{\mathcal{V}}\mathcal{C}\longrightarrow\mathcal{V}Cop⊠V​C⟶V, we'd need to set up a morphism

C(A,A′)⊗VC(B,B′)⟶[C(B,K)⋔V∫Y[WYB,D(F(A),G(Y))]V,C(B′,K)⋔V∫Y[WYB′,D(F(A′),G(Y))]V]V\mathcal{C}(A,A')\otimes_{\mathcal{V}}\mathcal{C}(B,B') \longrightarrow \left[ \mathcal{C}(B,K)\pitchfork_\mathcal{V}\int_{Y}[W^{B}_{Y},\mathcal{D}(F(A),G(Y))]_{\mathcal{V}} , \mathcal{C}(B',K)\pitchfork_\mathcal{V}\int_{Y}[W^{B'}_{Y},\mathcal{D}(F(A'),G(Y))]_{\mathcal{V}} \right]_{\mathcal{V}}C(A,A′)⊗V​C(B,B′)⟶[C(B,K)⋔V​∫Y​[WYB​,D(F(A),G(Y))]V​,C(B′,K)⋔V​∫Y​[WYB′​,D(F(A′),G(Y))]V​]V​

which would in particular require having a map

C(B,B′)⊗V(C(B,K)⋔V∫Y[WYB,D(F(A),G(Y))]V)⟶C(B′,K)⋔V∫Y[WYB′,D(F(A),G(Y))]V\mathcal{C}(\textcolor{red}{B},\textcolor{blue}{B'}) \otimes_{\mathcal{V}} \left( \mathcal{C}(\textcolor{red}{B},K)\pitchfork_\mathcal{V}\int_{Y}[W^{\textcolor{red}{B}}_{Y},\mathcal{D}(F(A),G(Y))]_{\mathcal{V}} \right) \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}(\textcolor{blue}{B'},K)\pitchfork_\mathcal{V}\int_{Y}[W^{\textcolor{blue}{B'}}_{Y},\mathcal{D}(F(A),G(Y))]_{\mathcal{V}}C(B,B′)⊗V​(C(B,K)⋔V​∫Y​[WYB​,D(F(A),G(Y))]V​)⟶C(B′,K)⋔V​∫Y​[WYB′​,D(F(A),G(Y))]V​

(is using colour okay for you, Matteo?)

so we still need some kind of duplication :/

¹We'll set K=YK=YK=Y in the end, but let's stick with KKK for the moment to differentiate between "YYY the object" and "YYY the integration variable"

Also, this is completely unrelated to the above, but here's something nice: a main example of a WWW-weighted natural transformation is for W=HomC(−1,−2)W=\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(-_{1},-_{2})W=HomC​(−1​,−2​): in this case, a Hom\mathrm{Hom}Hom-weighted natural transformation is precisely a dinatural one =)

On the nLab page, it states that enriched dinatural transformations only make sense when the enriching category is cartesian. Presumably this is related to the fact that you don't seem to be able to avoid requiring diagonals?

Théo said:

(is using colour okay for you, Matteo?)

Absolutely :) thanks for asking

Théo said:

Also, this is completely unrelated to the above, but here's something nice: a main example of a WWW-weighted natural transformation is for W=HomC(−1,−2)W=\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(-_{1},-_{2})W=HomC​(−1​,−2​): in this case, a Hom\mathrm{Hom}Hom-weighted natural transformation is precisely a dinatural one =)

This is very cool

Théo said:

Matteo Capucci (he/him) said:

The idea is to work with (X,Y,X′,Y′)↦[WYX,D(FX′,GY′)]V(X,Y,X',Y') \mapsto [W^X_Y, \mathcal D(FX', GY')]_{\mathcal V}(X,Y,X′,Y′)↦[WYX​,D(FX′,GY′)]V​ so we don't need to duplicate variables. Then we collapse the duplicate variables by imposing equality

This is a nice idea! I think we're still trapped though: the assignment

(A,B)↦∫Y[WYB,D(F(A),G(Y))]V(A,B) \mapsto \int_{Y}[W^{B}_{Y},\mathcal{D}(F(A),G(Y))]_{\mathcal{V}}(A,B)↦∫Y​[WYB​,D(F(A),G(Y))]V​

defines a V\mathcal{V}V-bifunctor ∫Y[WY−2,D(F(−1),G(Y))]V ⁣:Cop⊠VC⟶V\int_{Y}[W^{-_{2}}_{Y},\mathcal{D}(F(-_{1}),G(Y))]_{\mathcal{V}}\colon\mathcal{C}^{\mathsf{op}}\boxtimes_{\mathcal{V}}\mathcal{C}\longrightarrow\mathcal{V}∫Y​[WY−2​​,D(F(−1​),G(Y))]V​:Cop⊠V​C⟶V which when combined with¹ C(−,K) ⁣:Cop⟶V\mathcal{C}(-,K)\colon\mathcal{C}^\mathsf{op}\longrightarrow\mathcal{V}C(−,K):Cop⟶V would give a V\mathcal{V}V-functor

C(−3,K)⋔V∫Y[WY−2,D(F(−1),G(Y))]V\mathcal{C}(-_{3},K)\pitchfork_\mathcal{V}\int_{Y}[W^{-_{2}}_{Y},\mathcal{D}(F(-_{1}),G(Y))]_{\mathcal{V}}C(−3​,K)⋔V​∫Y​[WY−2​​,D(F(−1​),G(Y))]V​

from C⊠VCop⊠VC\mathcal{C}\boxtimes_{\mathcal{V}}\mathcal{C}^{\mathsf{op}}\boxtimes_{\mathcal{V}}\mathcal{C}C⊠V​Cop⊠V​C to V\mathcal{V}V. On the other hand, to get a functor Cop⊠VC⟶V\mathcal{C}^{\mathsf{op}}\boxtimes_{\mathcal{V}}\mathcal{C}\longrightarrow\mathcal{V}Cop⊠V​C⟶V, we'd need to set up a morphism

C(A,A′)⊗VC(B,B′)⟶[C(B,K)⋔V∫Y[WYB,D(F(A),G(Y))]V,C(B′,K)⋔V∫Y[WYB′,D(F(A′),G(Y))]V]V\mathcal{C}(A,A')\otimes_{\mathcal{V}}\mathcal{C}(B,B') \longrightarrow \left[ \mathcal{C}(B,K)\pitchfork_\mathcal{V}\int_{Y}[W^{B}_{Y},\mathcal{D}(F(A),G(Y))]_{\mathcal{V}} , \mathcal{C}(B',K)\pitchfork_\mathcal{V}\int_{Y}[W^{B'}_{Y},\mathcal{D}(F(A'),G(Y))]_{\mathcal{V}} \right]_{\mathcal{V}}C(A,A′)⊗V​C(B,B′)⟶[C(B,K)⋔V​∫Y​[WYB​,D(F(A),G(Y))]V​,C(B′,K)⋔V​∫Y​[WYB′​,D(F(A′),G(Y))]V​]V​

which would in particular require having a map

C(B,B′)⊗V(C(B,K)⋔V∫Y[WYB,D(F(A),G(Y))]V)⟶C(B′,K)⋔V∫Y[WYB′,D(F(A),G(Y))]V\mathcal{C}(\textcolor{red}{B},\textcolor{blue}{B'}) \otimes_{\mathcal{V}} \left( \mathcal{C}(\textcolor{red}{B},K)\pitchfork_\mathcal{V}\int_{Y}[W^{\textcolor{red}{B}}_{Y},\mathcal{D}(F(A),G(Y))]_{\mathcal{V}} \right) \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}(\textcolor{blue}{B'},K)\pitchfork_\mathcal{V}\int_{Y}[W^{\textcolor{blue}{B'}}_{Y},\mathcal{D}(F(A),G(Y))]_{\mathcal{V}}C(B,B′)⊗V​(C(B,K)⋔V​∫Y​[WYB​,D(F(A),G(Y))]V​)⟶C(B′,K)⋔V​∫Y​[WYB′​,D(F(A),G(Y))]V​

(is using colour okay for you, Matteo?)

so we still need some kind of duplication :/

¹We'll set K=YK=YK=Y in the end, but let's stick with KKK for the moment to differentiate between "YYY the object" and "YYY the integration variable"

So if I understand what you're saying, we still get into trouble when we try to define the inner end as a universal wedge?

Nathanael Arkor said:

On the nLab page, it states that enriched dinatural transformations only make sense when the enriching category is cartesian. Presumably this is related to the fact that you don't seem to be able to avoid requiring diagonals?

It is! I think this statement in the nLab comes from Remark 4.3.8 of version 5 of Fosco's book, who first worked this out. The point there was precisely that we need diagonals to define V\mathcal{V}V-dinaturality. Requiring V\mathcal{V}V to be Cartesian works, but the weaker condition of having diagonals suffices =)

Matteo Capucci (he/him) said:

So if I understand what you're saying, we still get into trouble when we try to define the inner end as a universal wedge?

The inner end works, i think the problem is to combine it with C(A,B)\mathcal{C}(A,B)C(A,B): the cotensor lets us take two V\mathcal{V}V-functors F,G ⁣:C⇉VF,G\colon\mathcal{C}\rightrightarrows\mathcal{V}F,G:C⇉V and form another V\mathcal{V}V-functor F⋔G ⁣:Cop⊠VC⟶VF\pitchfork G\colon\mathcal{C}^\mathsf{op}\boxtimes_{\mathcal{V}}\mathcal{C}\longrightarrow\mathcal{V}F⋔G:Cop⊠V​C⟶V. However, doing this for F=C(−1,K)F=\mathcal{C}(-_{1},K)F=C(−1​,K) and G=∫Y[WY−2,D(F(−1),G(Y))]VG=\int_{Y}[W^{-_{2}}_{Y},\mathcal{D}(F(-_{1}),G(Y))]_{\mathcal{V}}G=∫Y​[WY−2​​,D(F(−1​),G(Y))]V​ doesn't give us the correct V\mathcal{V}V-functor, as it goes from Cop⊠VC⊠VC\mathcal{C}^{\mathsf{op}}\boxtimes_\mathcal{V}\mathcal{C}\boxtimes_\mathcal{V}\mathcal{C}Cop⊠V​C⊠V​C to V\mathcal{V}V, rather than from Cop⊠VC\mathcal{C}^{\mathsf{op}}\boxtimes_\mathcal{V}\mathcal{C}Cop⊠V​C to V\mathcal{V}V: cotensoring together the codomains of FFF and GGG doesn't give us something we can take a coend of :/

So we might then try to define it by hand. However, for its components on the Hom-objects, you find that C(B,B′)\mathcal{C}(B,B')C(B,B′) has to act on two variables at once: the components of the V\mathcal{V}V-functors above go

C(B,B′)⊗VC(B,K)⟶C(B′,K)\mathcal{C}(\textcolor{red}{B},\textcolor{blue}{B'}) \otimes_{\mathcal{V}}\mathcal{C}(\textcolor{red}{B},K) \longrightarrow \mathcal{C}(\textcolor{blue}{B'},K)C(B,B′)⊗V​C(B,K)⟶C(B′,K)

and

C(B,B′)⊗V∫Y[WYB,D(F(A),G(Y))]V⟶∫Y[WYB′,D(F(A),G(Y))]V\mathcal{C}(\textcolor{red}{B},\textcolor{blue}{B'}) \otimes_{\mathcal{V}}\int_{Y}[W^{\textcolor{red}{B}}_{Y},\mathcal{D}(F(A),G(Y))]_{\mathcal{V}} \longrightarrow \int_{Y}[W^{\textcolor{blue}{B'}}_{Y},\mathcal{D}(F(A),G(Y))]_{\mathcal{V}}C(B,B′)⊗V​∫Y​[WYB​,D(F(A),G(Y))]V​⟶∫Y​[WYB′​,D(F(A),G(Y))]V​

So since we "use up" one C(B,B′)\mathcal{C}(\textcolor{red}{B},\textcolor{blue}{B'})C(B,B′) on each action, to combine them both into a cotensor would require more C(B,B′)\mathcal{C}(\textcolor{red}{B},\textcolor{blue}{B'})C(B,B′)'s than we have, and a solution to this would be to have a diagonal map C(B,B′)⟶C(B,B′)⊗VC(B,B′)\mathcal{C}(\textcolor{red}{B},\textcolor{blue}{B'})\longrightarrow\mathcal{C}(\textcolor{red}{B},\textcolor{blue}{B'})\otimes_{\mathcal{V}}\mathcal{C}(\textcolor{red}{B},\textcolor{blue}{B'})C(B,B′)⟶C(B,B′)⊗V​C(B,B′)

(By the way, defining WWW-weighted natural transformations as above and defining V\mathcal{V}V-dinaturality via a "formula" like

DiNatV(F,G)“=”∫XC(FXX,GXX)\mathrm{DiNat}_{\mathcal{V}}(F,G) \text{``$=$''} \int_{X}\mathcal{C}(F^{X}_{X},G^{X}_{X})DiNatV​(F,G)“=”∫X​C(FXX​,GXX​)

turn out to be equivalent! if we can do one of them, we can do both =)
Ok so maybe there's no hope, by the remark in Fosco's book you linked above

Matteo Capucci (he/him) said:

Something like

∫X∈CC(X,Y)⋔V∫Y∈C[WYX,D(FX,GY)]V\int_{X \in \mathcal C} \mathcal C(X, Y) \pitchfork_{\mathcal V} \int_{Y \in \mathcal C} [W^X_Y, \mathcal D(FX, GY)]_{\mathcal V}∫X∈C​C(X,Y)⋔V​∫Y∈C​[WYX​,D(FX,GY)]V​

Also, now that I take a fresh look at it, this doesn't make sense: I use YYY out of scope. Also my attempt is doomed by the start: in the formula φ(x,y)∧x=y\varphi(x,y) \land x = yφ(x,y)∧x=y, you see both xxx and yyy are still duplicated, so I don't get rid of the need of diagonals...
It's so frustrating though
It is!!
I've tried a lot of different strategies, but they all failed :/

I wonder if maybe "DiNatV(F,G)\mathbf{DiNat}_\mathcal{V}(F,G)DiNatV​(F,G) exists"¹ implies "V\mathcal{V}V has diagonals"

¹in some sense, e.g. "for each pair (F,G)(F,G)(F,G) of parallel functors Cop⊠VC⇉D\mathcal{C}^\mathsf{op}\boxtimes_\mathcal{V}\mathcal{C}\rightrightarrows\mathcal{D}Cop⊠V​C⇉D, there exists an object DiNatV(F,G)\mathbf{DiNat}_\mathcal{V}(F,G)DiNatV​(F,G) of V\mathcal{V}V satisfying the following properties"
Actually maybe this might be a good idea? Can one axiomatise dinatural transformations in terms of their properties?

Théo said:

I wonder if maybe "DiNatV(F,G)\mathbf{DiNat}_\mathcal{V}(F,G)DiNatV​(F,G) exists"¹ implies "V\mathcal{V}V has diagonals"

I think so... Indeed, to 'weigh' a functor one needs to use up a variable twice: one to compute the weight and one to compute the functor. So it's not a 'linear' operation.

Théo said:

:thinking: maybe?
I'll think more about this; it seems quite promising!
Thanks so much for this conversation!! :smiley:
:blush: Thanks to you for starting it!

@Matteo Capucci (he/him) and @Nathanael Arkor: I finally figured out how this works! I think we indeed can't define DiNatV(F,G)\mathbf{DiNat}_{\mathcal{V}}(F,G)DiNatV​(F,G) in general: there seems to be a kind of microcosm principle going on here, and the answer is to enrich in CoMon(V)\mathsf{CoMon}(\mathcal{V})CoMon(V) instead:

  • First, the reason this is not an issue in ordinary category theory is because CoMon(V)≅V\mathsf{CoMon}(\mathcal{V})\cong\mathcal{V}CoMon(V)≅V for V\mathcal{V}V Cartesian monoidal, and hence CatsCoMon(V)≅CatsV\mathsf{Cats}_{\mathsf{CoMon}(\mathcal{V})}\cong\mathsf{Cats}_{\mathcal{V}}CatsCoMon(V)​≅CatsV​ also, so CoMon(Sets)\mathsf{CoMon}(\mathsf{Sets})CoMon(Sets)-enriched categories are just plain categories.
  • Second, the comultiplication maps on the Homs: they are exactly what you need to define DiNatV(F,G)\mathbf{DiNat}_{\mathcal{V}}(F,G)DiNatV​(F,G) (the comonoid axioms are used to show that it is functorial, for instance);

  • Second+1/2: There's a kind of "loss of Ek\mathbb{E}_{k}Ek​-ness" going on for dinaturality (like taking categories of monoids of ordinary, braided, or symmetric monoidal categories gives a category, a monoidal category, or a symmetric monoidal category respectively):
    - For V\mathcal{V}V-enrichment, DiNatV(F,G)\mathbf{DiNat}_{\mathcal{V}}(F,G)DiNatV​(F,G) can't be defined;
    - For CoMon(V)\mathsf{CoMon}(\mathcal{V})CoMon(V)-enrichment, DiNatV(F,G)\mathbf{DiNat}_{\mathcal{V}}(F,G)DiNatV​(F,G) is an object of V\mathcal{V}V;
    - For CCoMon(V)\mathsf{CCoMon}(\mathcal{V})CCoMon(V)-enrichment, DiNatV(F,G)\mathbf{DiNat}_{\mathcal{V}}(F,G)DiNatV​(F,G) is a comonoid in V\mathcal{V}V (and happens to be also a cocommutative one for enriched categories, but this won't happen at this level of cocommutativity for enriched ∞\infty∞-categories).
    So F,G↦DiNatV(F,G)F,G\mapsto\mathbf{DiNat}_{\mathcal{V}}(F,G)F,G↦DiNatV​(F,G) gives a functor from pairs of functors enriched in Ek\mathbb{E}_kEk​-coalgebras in V\mathcal{V}V to Ek−1\mathbb{E}_{k-1}Ek−1​-coalgebras in V\mathcal{V}V, where "E0\mathbb{E}_{0}E0​" corresponds to just an object in V\mathcal{V}V, E1\mathbb{E}_{1}E1​ to a comonoid, and E2=E3=⋯\mathbb{E}_{2}=\mathbb{E}_{3}=\cdotsE2​=E3​=⋯ to a cocommutative comonoid.

  • Third: the counit maps turn out to be exactly what you need to define constant V\mathcal{V}V-functors!

That's really fascinating! It is very surprising to me that there's a connection between dinaturality (which to me seems a way to capture mixed variance) and (higher) comonoidal structure. I'd love to understand what's going on more conceptually. Does this mean you can carry out the development of weighted natural transformations as discussed above?

Note that the monoidal structure of CCoMon(V)\mathsf{CCoMon}(\mathcal{V})CCoMon(V) is cartesian. So passing to more-commutative comonoids is a way of making the monoidal structure "closer to cartesian".
@Théo wow, this is beautiful
@Nathanael Arkor @Matteo Capucci (he/him) I'm very happy that you liked this idea! :smiley:
@Mike Shulman I had no idea these were the products in CCoMon(V)\mathsf{CCoMon}(\mathcal{V})CCoMon(V), amazing!

Nathanael Arkor said:

That's really fascinating! It is very surprising to me that there's a connection between dinaturality (which to me seems a way to capture mixed variance) and (higher) comonoidal structure. I'd love to understand what's going on more conceptually. Does this mean you can carry out the development of weighted natural transformations as discussed above?

The reason the "reduction of cocommutativity" appears is because of Eckmann–Hilton: given V\mathcal{V}V-functors F,G ⁣:Cop⊠VC⇉DF,G\colon\mathcal{C}^{\mathsf{op}}\boxtimes_{\mathcal{V}}\mathcal{C}\rightrightarrows\mathcal{D}F,G:Cop⊠V​C⇉D, we'd like to define DiNatV(F,G)\mathbf{DiNat}_{\mathcal{V}}(F,G)DiNatV​(F,G) as the V\mathcal{V}V-end of the assignment

(A,B)↦HomD(FAB,GBA).(A,B)\mapsto\mathbf{Hom}_{\mathcal{D}}(F^{B}_{A},G^{A}_{B}).(A,B)↦HomD​(FAB​,GBA​).

However, to make this V\mathcal{V}V-functorial, we need a "comultiplication" ΔC ⁣:C→C⊠VC\Delta_{\mathcal{C}}\colon\mathcal{C}\to\mathcal{C}\boxtimes_{\mathcal{V}}\mathcal{C}ΔC​:C→C⊠V​C, as HomD(F−1−2,G−2−1)\mathbf{Hom}_{\mathcal{D}}(F^{-_{2}}_{-_{1}},G^{-_{1}}_{-_{2}})HomD​(F−1​−2​​,G−2​−1​​) is then given by the composition

image.png

It is here that the reduction of cocommutativity appears: for ΔC\Delta_{\mathcal{C}}ΔC​ to exist, we need an enrichment in CoMon(V)\mathsf{CoMon}(\mathcal{V})CoMon(V), and for it to be a CoMon(V)\mathsf{CoMon}(\mathcal{V})CoMon(V)-functor, we need an enrichment in CCoMon(V)\mathsf{CCoMon}(\mathcal{V})CCoMon(V): being CoMon(V)\mathsf{CoMon}(\mathcal{V})CoMon(V)-functorial means in particular that the comultiplication morphisms HomC(A,B)→HomC(A,B)⊗VHomC(A,B)\mathbf{Hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(A,B)\to\mathbf{Hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(A,B)\otimes_{\mathcal{V}}\mathbf{Hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(A,B)HomC​(A,B)→HomC​(A,B)⊗V​HomC​(A,B) are morphisms of comonoids, and this is is equivalent to the Hom\mathbf{Hom}Hom- objects being cocommutative, by Eckmann–Hilton.

(This is essentially the many-object version of the isomorphism CCoMon(V)≅CoMon(CoMon(V))\mathsf{CCoMon}(\mathcal{V})\cong\mathsf{CoMon}(\mathsf{CoMon}(\mathcal{V}))CCoMon(V)≅CoMon(CoMon(V)), as we have CatsCoMon(V)≅CoMon(CatsV)\mathsf{Cats}_{\mathsf{CoMon}(\mathcal{V})}\cong\mathsf{CoMon}(\mathsf{Cats}_{\mathcal{V}})CatsCoMon(V)​≅CoMon(CatsV​), and then CatsCCoMon(V)≅CoMon(CatsCoMon(V))≅CCoMon(CatsV)\mathsf{Cats}_{\mathsf{CCoMon}(\mathcal{V})}\cong\mathsf{CoMon}(\mathsf{Cats}_{\mathsf{CoMon}(\mathcal{V})})\cong\mathsf{CCoMon}(\mathsf{Cats}_{\mathcal{V}})CatsCCoMon(V)​≅CoMon(CatsCoMon(V)​)≅CCoMon(CatsV​)!)

Nathanael Arkor said:

Does this mean you can carry out the development of weighted natural transformations as discussed above?

I think this definitely should work for defining weighted natural transformations, but there seems to be a new complication now: for an enrichment in CoMon(V)\mathsf{CoMon}(\mathcal{V})CoMon(V), DiNat exists and things go normally, but for an enrichment in CCoMon(V)\mathsf{CCoMon}(\mathcal{V})CCoMon(V), it actually exists too much! We have both

  • A V\mathcal{V}V-functor HomD(F−1−2,G−2−1) ⁣:Cop⊠VC⟶V\mathbf{Hom}_{\mathcal{D}}(F^{-_{2}}_{-_{1}},G^{-_{1}}_{-_{2}})\colon\mathcal{C}^{\mathsf{op}}\boxtimes_{\mathcal{V}}\mathcal{C}\longrightarrow\mathcal{V}HomD​(F−1​−2​​,G−2​−1​​):Cop⊠V​C⟶V,
  • A CoMon(V)\mathsf{CoMon}(\mathcal{V})CoMon(V)-functor HomD(F−1−2,G−2−1) ⁣:Cop⊠CoMon(V)C⟶CoMon(V)\mathbf{Hom}_{\mathcal{D}}(F^{-_{2}}_{-_{1}},G^{-_{1}}_{-_{2}})\colon\mathcal{C}^{\mathsf{op}}\boxtimes_{\mathsf{CoMon(\mathcal{V})}}\mathcal{C}\longrightarrow\mathsf{CoMon}(\mathcal{V})HomD​(F−1​−2​​,G−2​−1​​):Cop⊠CoMon(V)​C⟶CoMon(V), and
  • A CCoMon(V)\mathsf{CCoMon}(\mathcal{V})CCoMon(V)-functor HomD(F−1−2,G−2−1) ⁣:Cop⊠CCoMon(V)C⟶CCoMon(V)\mathbf{Hom}_{\mathcal{D}}(F^{-_{2}}_{-_{1}},G^{-_{1}}_{-_{2}})\colon\mathcal{C}^{\mathsf{op}}\boxtimes_{\mathsf{CCoMon(\mathcal{V})}}\mathcal{C}\longrightarrow\mathsf{CCoMon}(\mathcal{V})HomD​(F−1​−2​​,G−2​−1​​):Cop⊠CCoMon(V)​C⟶CCoMon(V);
    and taking V\mathcal{V}V-, CoMon(V)\mathsf{CoMon}(\mathcal{V})CoMon(V)-, or CCoMon(V)\mathsf{CCoMon}(\mathcal{V})CCoMon(V)-ends of these functors will give different universal properties!

(It also doesn't help that it's somewhat hard to find interesting examples of categories enriched in (cocommutative) comonoids for non-Cartesian V\mathcal{V}V :sweat_smile:)

(Edit: actually I'm a bit confused now: if say Hom(F,G) is a CoMon(V)-functor, then we may take its CoMon(V)-end, but the universal property of ends gives a comonoid structure on its V-end as well; are these two comonoids isomorphic?)

But still, I'm pretty sure this should work, even if we end up having three different Nat[W](F,G)\mathbf{Nat}^{[W]}(F,G)Nat[W](F,G)'s, with three levels of "strength" for the associated universal properties...

(In any case, I think this should definitely be worth the trouble: weighted natural transformations pave the way to a lot of very nice constructions: they allow you to define weighted co/ends, weighted Kan extensions, weighted adjunctions, weighted co/monads, "coend-y" versions of adjunctions, monads, and Kan extensions (i.e. which are to co/ends what ordinary adjunctions, monads, and Kan extensions are to co/limits), a way to (vertically) compose dinatural transformations into "higher" dinatural ones (i.e. natural transformations weighted by Hom2\mathrm{Hom}^{2}Hom2, Hom3\mathrm{Hom}^{3}Hom3, and so on, which turn out to be related to conjugacy classes), notions of weighted co/limits which come with universal weighted co/cones (i.e. universal elements of Nat[W](Δlim[W](D),D)\mathrm{Nat}^{[W]}(\Delta_{\mathrm{lim}^{[W]}(D)},D)Nat[W](Δlim[W](D)​,D)), conical co/limits defined through constant enriched functors, and probably other nice things!)

This does sound very interesting, but my intuition is definitely struggling now! I think I will need to wait for some examples to understand how to think about these variations. I was also wondering about some examples of CoMon(V)\mathsf{CoMon(\mathcal V)}CoMon(V)-enriched categories… Looking forward to seeing where this goes next!
